columns.text: In this problem, we will determine the importance of evaluating projects using the equivalent annual cost (EAC).

The equivalent annual cost (EAC) is the method of comparing projects that have unequal lifespans based on their cost-effectiveness. This is important since it gives an overview of the costs the project incurs annually throughout its lifespan so even if the projects have unequal lifespans, they can still be compared quantitatively.

A low equivalent annual cost is preferred since it shows that the project is cost-effective and therefore there is a larger room for profit. However, one of the reasons that the equivalent annual cost may not be a good measure is that it does not consider the inflation rate. Aside from that, it only measures the cost so the difference in the technologies and innovations are not considered. This may give a faulty evaluation since a project may have higher annual cost but better innovations.
This question requires us to identify the appropriate method for the equivalent annual cost (EAC) analysis.

Just before making comparisons consensually preferential products of different lives that would be supplanted once those carry out, the EAC approach is well suited. This type of evaluation is required just so the initiatives can be completed. More or less, every undertaking is believed to have been built across an imaginary horizontal of N-year reiterating projects.

Supposing that somehow this sort of analysis is correct indicative of the fact that the projected future cash flows will remain constant in perpetuity, neglecting the repercussions of, among several other things, 

1. rising prices
2. adapting the macroeconomic environment, 
3. the vastly increased fragility of cash flow forecasts that take place far in the years ahead, and 
4. the potential impacts of future technological advancement might reflect the project cash flows.
